posts.name: Ariana
posts.cooked: Im in a JV robotics team and our gamepiece is a 5 inch diameter pickleball. We’ve found a shooter design were gonna use but its made for a soft ball and has 2 inch compression. We’re planning to use some sort of foam layer or roller for a flywheel shooter but i js wanted to ask whats and ideal compression range for this type of ball?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
As a rule of thumb, softer ball, harder shooter wheel(s), more compression; harder ball, softer wheels, less compression.

That said, the best way to determine the best wheel/compression for any particular ball is to prototype various options.

I’ve never shot a pickleball, but someone who has might be able to give you good starting values for one.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: I’d look at the compression sizes teams used for 2017 and scale it accordingly for the correct diameter. I’ve never held one in real life,  but a pickleball looks just like ‘Fuel’ to me and teams did launch them that year.

posts.name: Ariana
posts.cooked: Is there a general range that wr should make the first prototype with?

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: What is the competition or is this for school.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Typically we start at no compression and then advance in 0.5" increments, so (0.0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, …) until it’s obvious that more is unlikely to be useful).  Then we might experiment with different wheels ( Compliant Wheels - AndyMark, Inc ).

posts.name: Ariana
posts.cooked: So would the 0.0 be without a foam layer? And then we add?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
we don’t use any foam layer.  0.0 would be wheels just touching the ball.

[edit:] found a picture of our shooter prototyper – note the concentric arcs – these were CNC’d into the plywood sides to allow easy testing of various compressions. BTW, I would recommend using thicker plywood with deeper grooves, this one was hard to work with IMG_2267 1125×2436 7.92 MB
